name: Portrait Of An Artist: Velazquez Quiz | People | 10 Questions

questions.text: In what city was Diego Velazquez born in 1599?
questions.explanation:
Seville.

	He did much of his formative work in his hometown of Seville.

questions.text: Who was Velazquez's teacher and father-in-law?
questions.explanation:
Pacheco.

	Pacheco was never the painter that Velazquez was, but was an excellent pedagogue and suggested to Velazquez that he 'go to nature for everything'.

questions.text: Which of the following was not a painting by Velazquez?
questions.explanation:
The 3rd of May.

	The 3rd of May was a painting by another Spanish master painter, Francisco Goya.

questions.text: In 1623, Velazquez painted a portrait of the Spanish king which so pleased the king that henceforth, he declared only Velazquez could paint his likeness. Who was this king?
questions.explanation:
Philip IV.

	Velazquez, who was 6 years older than King Philip, remained in his service for his entire career.

questions.text: In the years 1628-9, what well-known Flemish painter visited Spain on a diplomatic mission, only to befriend Velazquez?
questions.explanation:
Peter Paul Rubens.

	Greatness touching greatness, and the rest of us can just stand in awe.

questions.text: The meeting with this painter apparently sparked Velazquez to do which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Make a pilgrimage to Italy.

	To Italy he went and found influence, particularly from the great Venetian masters of the past.

questions.text: Velazquez had a penchant for portraying which of the following in his works?
questions.explanation:
Dwarfs and court fools.

	He really did wonderful paintings of dwarfs, who were always retained in the royal court of Spain.

questions.text: It is widely believed that his masterwork of historical painting was which of his works?
questions.explanation:
The Surrender of Breda.

	The other choices here were of mythological or religious subjects.

questions.text: Perhaps Velazquez's greatest and most widely copied portrait (by artists such as Francis Bacon) was of a pope. Which pope was immortalized in this work?
questions.explanation:
Innocent X.

	Much like the Mona Lisa, it appears as if the pope is gazing right at you.

questions.text: The painting 'Las Meninas', arguably his greatest work, is now housed in what well-known museum?
questions.explanation:
The Prado.

	Fittingly, the greatest work of the greatest Spanish master now hangs on a wall in the Prado, in Madrid, the capital of Spain.
